trans-unit.source: Create a .NET MVC web app in Azure App Service with AD FS authentication
trans-unit.target: Create a .NET MVC web app in Azure App Service with AD FS authentication

trans-unit.source: Learn how to create an ASP.NET MVC line-of-business application in Azure App Service Web Apps that authenticates with on-premise STS. This tutorial targets AD FS as the on-premise STS.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to create an ASP.NET MVC line-of-business application in Azure App Service Web Apps that authenticates with on-premise STS. This tutorial targets AD FS as the on-premise STS.

trans-unit.source: In this article, you will learn how to create an ASP.NET MVC line-of-business application in <linkText>Azure App Service Web Apps</linkText><title></title> using an on-premises <linkText>Active Directory Federation Services</linkText><title></title> as the identity provider.
trans-unit.target: In this article, you will learn how to create an ASP.NET MVC line-of-business application in <linkText>Azure App Service Web Apps</linkText><title></title> using an on-premises <linkText>Active Directory Federation Services</linkText><title></title> as the identity provider.

trans-unit.source: This scenario can work when you want to create line-of-business applications in Azure App Service Web Apps but your organization requires all data to be stored on-site.
trans-unit.target: This scenario can work when you want to create line-of-business applications in Azure App Service Web Apps but your organization requires all data to be stored on-site.

trans-unit.source: For an overview of the different enterprise authentication and authorization options for Azure App Service Web Apps, see <linkText>Use Active Directory for authentication in Azure App Service</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For an overview of the different enterprise authentication and authorization options for Azure App Service Web Apps, see <linkText>Use Active Directory for authentication in Azure App Service</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: You will build a basic ASP.NET application in Azure App Service Web Apps with the following features:
trans-unit.target: You will build a basic ASP.NET application in Azure App Service Web Apps with the following features:

trans-unit.source: Authenticates users against AD FS
trans-unit.target: Authenticates users against AD FS

trans-unit.source: Uses [Authorize] to authorize users for different actions
trans-unit.target: Uses [Authorize] to authorize users for different actions

trans-unit.source: Static configuration for both debugging in Visual Studio and publishing to App Service Web Apps (configure once, debug and publish anytime)
trans-unit.target: Static configuration for both debugging in Visual Studio and publishing to App Service Web Apps (configure once, debug and publish anytime)

trans-unit.source: If you want to get started with Azure App Service before signing up for an Azure account, go to <linkText>Try App Service</linkText><title></title>, where you can immediately create a short-lived starter web app in App Service.
trans-unit.target: If you want to get started with Azure App Service before signing up for an Azure account, go to <linkText>Try App Service</linkText><title></title>, where you can immediately create a short-lived starter web app in App Service.

trans-unit.source: No credit cards required; no commitments.
trans-unit.target: No credit cards required; no commitments.

trans-unit.source: You need the following to complete this tutorial:
trans-unit.target: You need the following to complete this tutorial:

trans-unit.source: An on-premises AD FS deployment (for an end-to-end walkthrough of the test lab that I use, see <linkText>Test Lab: Standalone STS with AD FS in Azure VM (for test only)</linkText><title></title>)
trans-unit.target: An on-premises AD FS deployment (for an end-to-end walkthrough of the test lab that I use, see <linkText>Test Lab: Standalone STS with AD FS in Azure VM (for test only)</linkText><title></title>)

trans-unit.source: Permissions to create relying party trusts in AD FS Management
trans-unit.target: Permissions to create relying party trusts in AD FS Management

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio 2013
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio 2013

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Azure SDK 2.5.1</linkText><title></title> or later
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Azure SDK 2.5.1</linkText><title></title> or later

trans-unit.source: The sample application in this tutorial, <linkText>WebApp-WSFederation-DotNet)</linkText><title></title>, is created by the Azure Active Directory team.
trans-unit.target: The sample application in this tutorial, <linkText>WebApp-WSFederation-DotNet)</linkText><title></title>, is created by the Azure Active Directory team.

trans-unit.source: Since AD FS supports WS-Federation, you can is it as a template to create new line-of-business applications with ease.
trans-unit.target: Since AD FS supports WS-Federation, you can is it as a template to create new line-of-business applications with ease.

trans-unit.source: It has the following features:
trans-unit.target: It has the following features:

trans-unit.source: Uses <linkText>WS-Federation</linkText><title></title> to authenticate with an on-premises AD FS deployment
trans-unit.target: Uses <linkText>WS-Federation</linkText><title></title> to authenticate with an on-premises AD FS deployment

trans-unit.source: Sign-in and sign-out functionality
trans-unit.target: Sign-in and sign-out functionality

trans-unit.source: Uses <linkText>Microsoft.Owin</linkText><title></title> (instead of Windows Identity Foundation, i.e. WIF), which is the future of ASP.NET and much simpler to set up for authentication and authorization than WIF
trans-unit.target: Uses <linkText>Microsoft.Owin</linkText><title></title> (instead of Windows Identity Foundation, i.e. WIF), which is the future of ASP.NET and much simpler to set up for authentication and authorization than WIF

trans-unit.source: Clone or download the sample solution at <linkText>WebApp-WSFederation-DotNet</linkText><title></title> to your local directory.
trans-unit.target: Clone or download the sample solution at <linkText>WebApp-WSFederation-DotNet</linkText><title></title> to your local directory.

trans-unit.source: The instructions at <linkText>README.md</linkText><title></title> shows you how to set up the application with Azure Active Directory, but in this tutorial you will set it up with AD FS, so follow the steps here instead.
trans-unit.target: The instructions at <linkText>README.md</linkText><title></title> shows you how to set up the application with Azure Active Directory, but in this tutorial you will set it up with AD FS, so follow the steps here instead.

trans-unit.source: Open the solution, and then open Controllers\AccountController.cs in the Solution Explorer.
trans-unit.target: Open the solution, and then open Controllers\AccountController.cs in the Solution Explorer.

trans-unit.source: You will see that the code simply issues an authentication challenge to authenticate the user using WS-Federation.
trans-unit.target: You will see that the code simply issues an authentication challenge to authenticate the user using WS-Federation.

trans-unit.source: All authentication is configured in App_Start\Startup.Auth.cs.
trans-unit.target: All authentication is configured in App_Start\Startup.Auth.cs.

trans-unit.source: Open App_Start\Startup.Auth.cs.
trans-unit.target: Open App_Start\Startup.Auth.cs.

trans-unit.source: In the ConfigureAuth method, note the line:
trans-unit.target: In the ConfigureAuth method, note the line:

trans-unit.source: In the OWIN world, this is really the bare minimum you need to configure WS-Federation authentication.
trans-unit.target: In the OWIN world, this is really the bare minimum you need to configure WS-Federation authentication.

trans-unit.source: This is must simpler and more elegant than WIF, where Web.config is injected with XML all over the place.
trans-unit.target: This is must simpler and more elegant than WIF, where Web.config is injected with XML all over the place.

trans-unit.source: The only information you need is the relying party's (RP) identifier and the URL of your AD FS service's metadata file.
trans-unit.target: The only information you need is the relying party's (RP) identifier and the URL of your AD FS service's metadata file.

trans-unit.source: Here's an example:
trans-unit.target: Here's an example:

trans-unit.source: RP identifier: https://contoso.com/MyLOBApp
trans-unit.target: RP identifier: https://contoso.com/MyLOBApp

trans-unit.source: Metadata address: http://adfs.contoso.com/FederationMetadata/2007-06/FederationMetadata.xml
trans-unit.target: Metadata address: http://adfs.contoso.com/FederationMetadata/2007-06/FederationMetadata.xml

trans-unit.source: In App_Start\Startup.Auth.cs, change the static string definitions as highlighted below:
trans-unit.target: In App_Start\Startup.Auth.cs, change the static string definitions as highlighted below:

trans-unit.source: private static string realm = ConfigurationManager.AppSettings["ida:
trans-unit.target: private static string realm = ConfigurationManager.AppSettings["ida:

trans-unit.source: RPIdentifier
trans-unit.target: RPIdentifier

trans-unit.source: private static string aadInstance = ConfigurationManager.AppSettings["ida:AADInstance"];
trans-unit.target: private static string aadInstance = ConfigurationManager.AppSettings["ida:AADInstance"];

trans-unit.source: private static string tenant = ConfigurationManager.AppSettings["ida:Tenant"];
trans-unit.target: private static string tenant = ConfigurationManager.AppSettings["ida:Tenant"];

trans-unit.source: private static string metadata = string.Format("{0}/{1}/federationmetadata/2007-06/federationmetadata.xml", aadInstance, tenant);
trans-unit.target: private static string metadata = string.Format("{0}/{1}/federationmetadata/2007-06/federationmetadata.xml", aadInstance, tenant);

trans-unit.source: private static string metadata = string.Format("https://{0}/federationmetadata/2007-06/federationmetadata.xml", ConfigurationManager.AppSettings["ida:ADFS"]);
trans-unit.target: private static string metadata = string.Format("https://{0}/federationmetadata/2007-06/federationmetadata.xml", ConfigurationManager.AppSettings["ida:ADFS"]);

trans-unit.source: string authority = String.Format(CultureInfo.InvariantCulture, aadInstance, tenant);
trans-unit.target: string authority = String.Format(CultureInfo.InvariantCulture, aadInstance, tenant);

trans-unit.source: You will now make the corresponding changes in Web.config.
trans-unit.target: You will now make the corresponding changes in Web.config.

trans-unit.source: Open the Web.config and modify the app settings as highlighted below:
trans-unit.target: Open the Web.config and modify the app settings as highlighted below:

trans-unit.source: <add key="ida:Wtrealm" value="[Enter the App ID URI of WebApp-WSFederation-DotNet https://contoso.onmicrosoft.com/WebApp-WSFederation-DotNet]" />
trans-unit.target: <add key="ida:Wtrealm" value="[Enter the App ID URI of WebApp-WSFederation-DotNet https://contoso.onmicrosoft.com/WebApp-WSFederation-DotNet]" />

trans-unit.source: <add key="ida:AADInstance" value="https://login.windows.net" />
trans-unit.target: <add key="ida:AADInstance" value="https://login.windows.net" />

trans-unit.source: <add key="ida:Tenant" value="[Enter tenant name, e.g. contoso.onmicrosoft.com]" />
trans-unit.target: <add key="ida:Tenant" value="[Enter tenant name, e.g. contoso.onmicrosoft.com]" />

trans-unit.source: <add key="ida:RPIdentifier" value="[Enter the relying party identifier as configured in AD FS, e.g. https://localhost:44320/]" />
trans-unit.target: <add key="ida:RPIdentifier" value="[Enter the relying party identifier as configured in AD FS, e.g. https://localhost:44320/]" />

trans-unit.source: <add key="ida:ADFS" value="[Enter the FQDN of AD FS service, e.g. adfs.contoso.com]" />
trans-unit.target: <add key="ida:ADFS" value="[Enter the FQDN of AD FS service, e.g. adfs.contoso.com]" />

trans-unit.source: </appSettings>
trans-unit.target: </appSettings>

trans-unit.source: Fill in the key values based on your respective environment.
trans-unit.target: Fill in the key values based on your respective environment.

trans-unit.source: Build the application to make sure there are no errors.
trans-unit.target: Build the application to make sure there are no errors.

trans-unit.source: That's it.
trans-unit.target: That's it.

trans-unit.source: Now the sample application is ready to work with AD FS.
trans-unit.target: Now the sample application is ready to work with AD FS.

trans-unit.source: You will still need to configure an RP trust with this application in AD FS later.
trans-unit.target: You will still need to configure an RP trust with this application in AD FS later.

trans-unit.source: Here, you will publish the application to a web app in App Service Web Apps while preserving the debug environment.
trans-unit.target: Here, you will publish the application to a web app in App Service Web Apps while preserving the debug environment.

trans-unit.source: Note that you're going to publish the application before it has an RP trust with AD FS, so authentication still doesn't work yet.
trans-unit.target: Note that you're going to publish the application before it has an RP trust with AD FS, so authentication still doesn't work yet.

trans-unit.source: However, if you do it now you can have the web app URL that you will also use to configure the RP trust later.
trans-unit.target: However, if you do it now you can have the web app URL that you will also use to configure the RP trust later.

trans-unit.source: Right-click your project and select Publish.
trans-unit.target: Right-click your project and select Publish.

trans-unit.source: Select Microsoft Azure Web Apps.
trans-unit.target: Select Microsoft Azure Web Apps.

trans-unit.source: If you haven't signed in to Azure, click Sign In and use the Microsoft account for your Azure subscription to sign in.
trans-unit.target: If you haven't signed in to Azure, click Sign In and use the Microsoft account for your Azure subscription to sign in.

trans-unit.source: Once signed in, click New to create a new web app.
trans-unit.target: Once signed in, click New to create a new web app.

trans-unit.source: Fill in all required fields.
trans-unit.target: Fill in all required fields.

trans-unit.source: You are going to connect to on-premise data later, so you won't create a database for this web app.
trans-unit.target: You are going to connect to on-premise data later, so you won't create a database for this web app.

trans-unit.source: Click Create.
trans-unit.target: Click Create.

trans-unit.source: Once the web app is created, the Publish Web dialog is opened.
trans-unit.target: Once the web app is created, the Publish Web dialog is opened.

trans-unit.source: In Destination URL, change http to https.
trans-unit.target: In Destination URL, change http to https.

trans-unit.source: Copy the entire URL to a text editor.
trans-unit.target: Copy the entire URL to a text editor.

trans-unit.source: You will use it later.
trans-unit.target: You will use it later.

trans-unit.source: Then, click Publish.
trans-unit.target: Then, click Publish.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, open Web.Release.config in your project. Insert the following XML into the tag, and replace the key value with your publish web app's URL.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, open Web.Release.config in your project. Insert the following XML into the tag, and replace the key value with your publish web app's URL.

trans-unit.source: <appSettings> <add key="ida:RPIdentifier" value="
trans-unit.target: <appSettings> <add key="ida:RPIdentifier" value="

trans-unit.source: [e.g. https://mylobapp.azurewebsites.net/]
trans-unit.target: [e.g. https://mylobapp.azurewebsites.net/]

trans-unit.source: " xdt:Transform="SetAttributes" xdt:Locator="Match(key)" /> </appSettings>
trans-unit.target: " xdt:Transform="SetAttributes" xdt:Locator="Match(key)" /> </appSettings>

trans-unit.source: When you're done, you have two RP identifiers configured in your project, one for your debug environment in Visual Studio, and one for the published web app in Azure.
trans-unit.target: When you're done, you have two RP identifiers configured in your project, one for your debug environment in Visual Studio, and one for the published web app in Azure.

trans-unit.source: You will set up an RP trust for each of the two environments in AD FS.
trans-unit.target: You will set up an RP trust for each of the two environments in AD FS.

trans-unit.source: During debugging, the app settings in Web.config is used to make your Debug configuration work with AD FS, and when it's published (by default, the Release configuration is published), a transformed Web.config is uploaded that incorporates the app setting changes in Web.Release.config.
trans-unit.target: During debugging, the app settings in Web.config is used to make your Debug configuration work with AD FS, and when it's published (by default, the Release configuration is published), a transformed Web.config is uploaded that incorporates the app setting changes in Web.Release.config.

trans-unit.source: If you want to attach the published web app in Azure to the debugger (i.e. you must upload debug symbols of your code in the published web app), you can create a clone of the Debug configuration for Azure debugging, but with its own custom Web.config transform (e.g. Web.AzureDebug.config) that uses the app settings from Web.Release.config.
trans-unit.target: If you want to attach the published web app in Azure to the debugger (i.e. you must upload debug symbols of your code in the published web app), you can create a clone of the Debug configuration for Azure debugging, but with its own custom Web.config transform (e.g. Web.AzureDebug.config) that uses the app settings from Web.Release.config.

trans-unit.source: This allows you to maintain a static configuration across the different environments.
trans-unit.target: This allows you to maintain a static configuration across the different environments.

trans-unit.source: Now you need to configure a RP trust in AD FS Mangement before you can your sample application can actually authenticate with AD FS.
trans-unit.target: Now you need to configure a RP trust in AD FS Mangement before you can your sample application can actually authenticate with AD FS.

trans-unit.source: You will need to set up two separate RP trusts, one for your debug environment and one for your published web app.
trans-unit.target: You will need to set up two separate RP trusts, one for your debug environment and one for your published web app.

trans-unit.source: Make sure that you repeat the steps below for both of your environments.
trans-unit.target: Make sure that you repeat the steps below for both of your environments.

trans-unit.source: On your AD FS server, log in with credentials that have management rights to AD FS.
trans-unit.target: On your AD FS server, log in with credentials that have management rights to AD FS.

trans-unit.source: Open AD FS Management.
trans-unit.target: Open AD FS Management.

trans-unit.source: Right-click AD FS\Trusted Relationships\Relying Party Trusts and select Add Relying Party Trust.
trans-unit.target: Right-click AD FS\Trusted Relationships\Relying Party Trusts and select Add Relying Party Trust.

trans-unit.source: In the Select Data Source page, select Enter data about the relying party manually.
trans-unit.target: In the Select Data Source page, select Enter data about the relying party manually.

trans-unit.source: In the Specify Display Name page, type a display name for the application and click Next.
trans-unit.target: In the Specify Display Name page, type a display name for the application and click Next.

trans-unit.source: In the Choose Protocol page, click Next.
trans-unit.target: In the Choose Protocol page, click Next.

trans-unit.source: In the Configure Certificate page, click Next.
trans-unit.target: In the Configure Certificate page, click Next.

trans-unit.source: Since you should be using HTTPS already, encrypted tokens are optional.
trans-unit.target: Since you should be using HTTPS already, encrypted tokens are optional.

trans-unit.source: If you really want to encrypt tokens from AD FS on this page, you must also add token-decrypting logic in your code.
trans-unit.target: If you really want to encrypt tokens from AD FS on this page, you must also add token-decrypting logic in your code.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>Manually configuring OWIN WS-Federation middleware and accepting encrypted tokens</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>Manually configuring OWIN WS-Federation middleware and accepting encrypted tokens</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Before you move onto the next step, you need one piece of information from your Visual Studio project.
trans-unit.target: Before you move onto the next step, you need one piece of information from your Visual Studio project.

trans-unit.source: In the project properties, note the SSL URL of the application.
trans-unit.target: In the project properties, note the SSL URL of the application.

trans-unit.source: Back in AD FS Management, in the Configure URL page of the Add Relying Party Trust Wizard, select Enable support for the WS-Federation Passive protocol and type in the SSL URL of your Visual Studio project that you noted in the previous step.
trans-unit.target: Back in AD FS Management, in the Configure URL page of the Add Relying Party Trust Wizard, select Enable support for the WS-Federation Passive protocol and type in the SSL URL of your Visual Studio project that you noted in the previous step.

trans-unit.source: Then, click Next.
trans-unit.target: Then, click Next.

trans-unit.source: URL specifies where to send the client after authentication succeeds.
trans-unit.target: URL specifies where to send the client after authentication succeeds.

trans-unit.source: For the debug environment, it should be https://localhost:<port>/.
trans-unit.target: For the debug environment, it should be https://localhost:<port>/.

trans-unit.source: For the published web app, it should be the web app URL.
trans-unit.target: For the published web app, it should be the web app URL.

trans-unit.source: In the Configure Identifiers page, verify that your project SSL URL is already listed and click Next.
trans-unit.target: In the Configure Identifiers page, verify that your project SSL URL is already listed and click Next.

trans-unit.source: Click Next all the way to the end of the wizard with default selections.
trans-unit.target: Click Next all the way to the end of the wizard with default selections.

trans-unit.source: In App_Start\Startup.Auth.cs of your Visual Studio project, this identifier is matched against the value of WsFederationAuthenticationOptions.Wtrealm during federated authentication.
trans-unit.target: In App_Start\Startup.Auth.cs of your Visual Studio project, this identifier is matched against the value of WsFederationAuthenticationOptions.Wtrealm during federated authentication.

trans-unit.source: By default, the application's URL from the previous step is added as an RP identifier.
trans-unit.target: By default, the application's URL from the previous step is added as an RP identifier.

trans-unit.source: You have now finished configuring the RP application for your project in AD FS.
trans-unit.target: You have now finished configuring the RP application for your project in AD FS.

trans-unit.source: Next, you will configure this application to send the claims needed by your application.
trans-unit.target: Next, you will configure this application to send the claims needed by your application.

trans-unit.source: The Edit Claim Rules dialog is opened by default for you at the end of the wizard so you can start immediately.
trans-unit.target: The Edit Claim Rules dialog is opened by default for you at the end of the wizard so you can start immediately.

trans-unit.source: Let's configure at least the following claims (with schemas in parentheses):
trans-unit.target: Let's configure at least the following claims (with schemas in parentheses):

trans-unit.source: Name (http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/05/identity/claims/name) - used by ASP.NET to hydrate User.Identity.Name.
trans-unit.target: Name (http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/05/identity/claims/name) - used by ASP.NET to hydrate User.Identity.Name.

trans-unit.source: User principal name (http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/05/identity/claims/upn) - used to uniquely identify users in the organization.
trans-unit.target: User principal name (http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/05/identity/claims/upn) - used to uniquely identify users in the organization.

trans-unit.source: Group memberships as roles (http://schemas.microsoft.com/ws/2008/06/identity/claims/role) - can be used with [Authorize(Roles="role1, role2,...")] decoration to authorize controllers/actions.
trans-unit.target: Group memberships as roles (http://schemas.microsoft.com/ws/2008/06/identity/claims/role) - can be used with [Authorize(Roles="role1, role2,...")] decoration to authorize controllers/actions.

trans-unit.source: In reality, this may not be the most performant approach for role authorization, especially if your AD users regularly belong to hundreds of security groups, which translates to hundreds of role claims in the SAML token.
trans-unit.target: In reality, this may not be the most performant approach for role authorization, especially if your AD users regularly belong to hundreds of security groups, which translates to hundreds of role claims in the SAML token.

trans-unit.source: An alternative approach is to send a single role claim conditionally depending on the user's membership in a particular group.
trans-unit.target: An alternative approach is to send a single role claim conditionally depending on the user's membership in a particular group.

trans-unit.source: However, we'll keep it simple for this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: However, we'll keep it simple for this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: Name ID (http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/05/identity/claims/nameidentifier) - can be used for anti-forgery validation.
trans-unit.target: Name ID (http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/05/identity/claims/nameidentifier) - can be used for anti-forgery validation.

trans-unit.source: For more information on how to make it work with anti-forgery validation, see the Add line-of-business functionality to the sample application section of Create a .NET MVC web app in Azure App Service with Azure Active Directory authentication.
trans-unit.target: For more information on how to make it work with anti-forgery validation, see the Add line-of-business functionality to the sample application section of Create a .NET MVC web app in Azure App Service with Azure Active Directory authentication.

trans-unit.source: The claim types you need to configure for your application is determined by your application's needs.
trans-unit.target: The claim types you need to configure for your application is determined by your application's needs.

trans-unit.source: For the list of claims supported by Azure Active Directory applications (i.e. RP trusts), for example, see <linkText>Supported Token and Claim Types</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For the list of claims supported by Azure Active Directory applications (i.e. RP trusts), for example, see <linkText>Supported Token and Claim Types</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: In the Edit Claim Rules dialog, click Add Rule.
trans-unit.target: In the Edit Claim Rules dialog, click Add Rule.

trans-unit.source: Configure the name, UPN, and role claims as shown below and click Finish.
trans-unit.target: Configure the name, UPN, and role claims as shown below and click Finish.

trans-unit.source: Next, you will create a transient name ID claim using the steps demonstrated in <linkText>Name Identifiers in SAML assertions</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Next, you will create a transient name ID claim using the steps demonstrated in <linkText>Name Identifiers in SAML assertions</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Click Add Rule again.
trans-unit.target: Click Add Rule again.

trans-unit.source: Select Send Claims Using a Custom Rule and click Next.
trans-unit.target: Select Send Claims Using a Custom Rule and click Next.

trans-unit.source: Paste the following rule language into the Custom rule box, name the rule Per Session Identifier and click Finish.
trans-unit.target: Paste the following rule language into the Custom rule box, name the rule Per Session Identifier and click Finish.

trans-unit.source: c1:[Type == "http://schemas.microsoft.com/ws/2008/06/identity/claims/windowsaccountname"] && c2:[Type == "http://schemas.microsoft.com/ws/2008/06/identity/claims/authenticationinstant"] => add( store = "_OpaqueIdStore", types = ("
trans-unit.target: c1:[Type == "http://schemas.microsoft.com/ws/2008/06/identity/claims/windowsaccountname"] && c2:[Type == "http://schemas.microsoft.com/ws/2008/06/identity/claims/authenticationinstant"] => add( store = "_OpaqueIdStore", types = ("

trans-unit.source: http://contoso.com/internal/sessionid
trans-unit.target: http://contoso.com/internal/sessionid

trans-unit.source: "), query = "{0};{1};{2};{3};{4}", param = "useEntropy", param = c1.Value, param = c1.OriginalIssuer, param = "", param = c2.Value);
trans-unit.target: "), query = "{0};{1};{2};{3};{4}", param = "useEntropy", param = c1.Value, param = c1.OriginalIssuer, param = "", param = c2.Value);

trans-unit.source: Your custom rule should look like this:
trans-unit.target: Your custom rule should look like this:

trans-unit.source: Click Add Rule again.
trans-unit.target: Click Add Rule again.

trans-unit.source: Select Transform an Incoming Claim and click Next.
trans-unit.target: Select Transform an Incoming Claim and click Next.

trans-unit.source: Configure the rule as shown below (using the claim type you created in the custom rule) and click Finish.
trans-unit.target: Configure the rule as shown below (using the claim type you created in the custom rule) and click Finish.

trans-unit.source: For detailed information on the steps for the transient Name ID claim above, see <linkText>Name Identifiers in SAML assertions</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For detailed information on the steps for the transient Name ID claim above, see <linkText>Name Identifiers in SAML assertions</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Click Apply in the Edit Claim Rules dialog.
trans-unit.target: Click Apply in the Edit Claim Rules dialog.

trans-unit.source: It should now look like the screenshot below:
trans-unit.target: It should now look like the screenshot below:

trans-unit.source: Again, make sure that you repeat these steps for both your debug environment and published web app.
trans-unit.target: Again, make sure that you repeat these steps for both your debug environment and published web app.

trans-unit.source: You are ready to test your application's authentication logic against AD FS.
trans-unit.target: You are ready to test your application's authentication logic against AD FS.

trans-unit.source: In my AD FS lab environment, I have a test user that belongs to a test group in Active Directory (AD).
trans-unit.target: In my AD FS lab environment, I have a test user that belongs to a test group in Active Directory (AD).

trans-unit.source: To test authentication in the debugger, all you need to do now is type F5.
trans-unit.target: To test authentication in the debugger, all you need to do now is type F5.

trans-unit.source: If you want to test authentication in the published web app, navigate to the URL.
trans-unit.target: If you want to test authentication in the published web app, navigate to the URL.

trans-unit.source: After the web application loads, click Sign In.
trans-unit.target: After the web application loads, click Sign In.

trans-unit.source: You should now get either a login dialog or the login page served by AD FS, depending on the authentication method chosen by AD FS.
trans-unit.target: You should now get either a login dialog or the login page served by AD FS, depending on the authentication method chosen by AD FS.

trans-unit.source: Here's what I get in Internet Explorer 11.
trans-unit.target: Here's what I get in Internet Explorer 11.

trans-unit.source: Once you log in with a user in the AD domain of the AD FS deployment, you should now see the homepage again with Hello, ! in the corner. Here's what I get.
trans-unit.target: Once you log in with a user in the AD domain of the AD FS deployment, you should now see the homepage again with Hello, ! in the corner. Here's what I get.

trans-unit.source: So far, you've succeeded in the following ways:
trans-unit.target: So far, you've succeeded in the following ways:

trans-unit.source: Your application has successfully reached AD FS and a matching RP identifier is found in the AD FS database
trans-unit.target: Your application has successfully reached AD FS and a matching RP identifier is found in the AD FS database

trans-unit.source: AD FS has successfully authenticated an AD user and redirect you back to the application's homepage
trans-unit.target: AD FS has successfully authenticated an AD user and redirect you back to the application's homepage

trans-unit.source: AD FS as successfully sent the name claim (http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/05/identity/claims/name) to your application, as indicated by the fact that the user name is displayed in the corner.
trans-unit.target: AD FS as successfully sent the name claim (http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/05/identity/claims/name) to your application, as indicated by the fact that the user name is displayed in the corner.

trans-unit.source: If the name claim is missing, you would have seen Hello, !.
trans-unit.target: If the name claim is missing, you would have seen Hello, !.

trans-unit.source: If you take a look at Views\Shared\_LoginPartial.cshtml, you will find that it uses User.Identity.Name to display the user name.
trans-unit.target: If you take a look at Views\Shared\_LoginPartial.cshtml, you will find that it uses User.Identity.Name to display the user name.

trans-unit.source: As mentioned previously, ASP.NET hydrates this property with the name claim of the authenticated user, if it is available in the SAML token.
trans-unit.target: As mentioned previously, ASP.NET hydrates this property with the name claim of the authenticated user, if it is available in the SAML token.

trans-unit.source: To see all the claims that are sent by AD FS, put a breakpoint in Controllers\HomeController.cs, in the Index action method.
trans-unit.target: To see all the claims that are sent by AD FS, put a breakpoint in Controllers\HomeController.cs, in the Index action method.

trans-unit.source: After the user is authenticated, inspect the System.Security.Claims.Current.Claims collection.
trans-unit.target: After the user is authenticated, inspect the System.Security.Claims.Current.Claims collection.

trans-unit.source: Since you have included group memberships as role claims in your RP trust configuration, you can now use these directly in the [Authorize(Roles="...")] decoration for controllers and actions.
trans-unit.target: Since you have included group memberships as role claims in your RP trust configuration, you can now use these directly in the [Authorize(Roles="...")] decoration for controllers and actions.

trans-unit.source: In a line-of-business application with the Create-Read-Update-Delete (CRUD) pattern, you can authorize specific roles to access each action.
trans-unit.target: In a line-of-business application with the Create-Read-Update-Delete (CRUD) pattern, you can authorize specific roles to access each action.

trans-unit.source: For now, you will just try out this feature on the existing Home controller.
trans-unit.target: For now, you will just try out this feature on the existing Home controller.

trans-unit.source: Open Controllers\HomeController.cs.
trans-unit.target: Open Controllers\HomeController.cs.

trans-unit.source: Decorate the About and Contact action methods similar to below, using security group memberships that your authenticated user has.
trans-unit.target: Decorate the About and Contact action methods similar to below, using security group memberships that your authenticated user has.

trans-unit.source: [Authorize(Roles="Test Group")]
trans-unit.target: [Authorize(Roles="Test Group")]

trans-unit.source: [Authorize(Roles="Domain Admins")]
trans-unit.target: [Authorize(Roles="Domain Admins")]

trans-unit.source: Since I added Test User to Test Group in my AD FS lab environment, I'll use Test Group to test authorization on About.
trans-unit.target: Since I added Test User to Test Group in my AD FS lab environment, I'll use Test Group to test authorization on About.

trans-unit.source: For Contact, I'll test the negative case of Domain Admins, to which Test User doesn't belong.
trans-unit.target: For Contact, I'll test the negative case of Domain Admins, to which Test User doesn't belong.

trans-unit.source: Start the debugger by typing F5 and sign in, then click About.
trans-unit.target: Start the debugger by typing F5 and sign in, then click About.

trans-unit.source: You should now be viewing the ~/About/Index page successfully, if your authenticated user is authorized for that action.
trans-unit.target: You should now be viewing the ~/About/Index page successfully, if your authenticated user is authorized for that action.

trans-unit.source: Now click Contact, which in my case should not authorize Test User for the action.
trans-unit.target: Now click Contact, which in my case should not authorize Test User for the action.

trans-unit.source: However, the browser is redirected to AD FS, which eventually shows this message:
trans-unit.target: However, the browser is redirected to AD FS, which eventually shows this message:

trans-unit.source: If you investigate this error in Event Viewer on the AD FS server, you will see this exception message:
trans-unit.target: If you investigate this error in Event Viewer on the AD FS server, you will see this exception message:

trans-unit.source: Microsoft.IdentityServer.Web.InvalidRequestException: MSIS7042:
trans-unit.target: Microsoft.IdentityServer.Web.InvalidRequestException: MSIS7042:

trans-unit.source: The same client browser session has made '6' requests in the last '11' seconds.
trans-unit.target: The same client browser session has made '6' requests in the last '11' seconds.

trans-unit.source: Contact your administrator for details. at Microsoft.IdentityServer.Web.Protocols.PassiveProtocolHandler.UpdateLoopDetectionCookie(WrappedHttpListenerContext context) at Microsoft.IdentityServer.Web.Protocols.WSFederation.WSFederationProtocolHandler.SendSignInResponse(WSFederationContext context, MSISSignInResponse response) at Microsoft.IdentityServer.Web.PassiveProtocolListener.ProcessProtocolRequest(ProtocolContext protocolContext, PassiveProtocolHandler protocolHandler) at Microsoft.IdentityServer.Web.PassiveProtocolListener.OnGetContext(WrappedHttpListenerContext context)
trans-unit.target: Contact your administrator for details. at Microsoft.IdentityServer.Web.Protocols.PassiveProtocolHandler.UpdateLoopDetectionCookie(WrappedHttpListenerContext context) at Microsoft.IdentityServer.Web.Protocols.WSFederation.WSFederationProtocolHandler.SendSignInResponse(WSFederationContext context, MSISSignInResponse response) at Microsoft.IdentityServer.Web.PassiveProtocolListener.ProcessProtocolRequest(ProtocolContext protocolContext, PassiveProtocolHandler protocolHandler) at Microsoft.IdentityServer.Web.PassiveProtocolListener.OnGetContext(WrappedHttpListenerContext context)

trans-unit.source: The reason this happens is that by default, MVC returns a 401 Unauthorized when a user's roles are not authorized.
trans-unit.target: The reason this happens is that by default, MVC returns a 401 Unauthorized when a user's roles are not authorized.

trans-unit.source: This triggers a reauthentication request to your identity provider (AD FS).
trans-unit.target: This triggers a reauthentication request to your identity provider (AD FS).

trans-unit.source: Since the user is already authenticated, AD FS returns to the same page, which then issues another 401, creating a redirect loop.
trans-unit.target: Since the user is already authenticated, AD FS returns to the same page, which then issues another 401, creating a redirect loop.

trans-unit.source: You will override AuthorizeAttribute's HandleUnauthorizedRequest method with simple logic to show something that makes sense instead of continuing the redirect loop.
trans-unit.target: You will override AuthorizeAttribute's HandleUnauthorizedRequest method with simple logic to show something that makes sense instead of continuing the redirect loop.

trans-unit.source: Create a file in the project called AuthorizeAttribute.cs, and paste the code below into it.
trans-unit.target: Create a file in the project called AuthorizeAttribute.cs, and paste the code below into it.

trans-unit.source: The override code sends an HTTP 403 (Forbidden) instead of HTTP 401 (Unauthorized) in authenticated-but-unauthorized cases.
trans-unit.target: The override code sends an HTTP 403 (Forbidden) instead of HTTP 401 (Unauthorized) in authenticated-but-unauthorized cases.

trans-unit.source: Run the debugger again with F5.
trans-unit.target: Run the debugger again with F5.

trans-unit.source: Clicking Contact now shows a more informative (albeit unattractive) error message:
trans-unit.target: Clicking Contact now shows a more informative (albeit unattractive) error message:

trans-unit.source: Publish the application to Azure App Service Web Apps again, and test the behavior of the live application.
trans-unit.target: Publish the application to Azure App Service Web Apps again, and test the behavior of the live application.

trans-unit.source: A reason that you would want to implement your line-of-business application with AD FS instead of Azure Active Directory is compliance issues with keeping organization data off-premise.
trans-unit.target: A reason that you would want to implement your line-of-business application with AD FS instead of Azure Active Directory is compliance issues with keeping organization data off-premise.

trans-unit.source: This may also mean that your web app in Azure must access on-premise databases, since you are not allowed to use <linkText>SQL Database</linkText><title></title> as the data tier for your web apps.
trans-unit.target: This may also mean that your web app in Azure must access on-premise databases, since you are not allowed to use <linkText>SQL Database</linkText><title></title> as the data tier for your web apps.

trans-unit.source: Azure App Service Web Apps supports accessing on-premise databases with two approaches: <linkText>Hybrid Connections</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>Virtual Networks</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Azure App Service Web Apps supports accessing on-premise databases with two approaches: <linkText>Hybrid Connections</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>Virtual Networks</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>Using VNET integration and Hybrid connections with Azure App Service Web Apps</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>Using VNET integration and Hybrid connections with Azure App Service Web Apps</linkText><title></title>.
